What are the changes that have been made to get us ready for the school year at the elementary?

Extra space was made in the classrooms to ensure desks are six feet apart. Extra furniture and materials have been placed in a storage trailer.

Seating in the cafeteria has been doubled by setting up tables in the multi-purpose room to accommodate breakfast and lunch.

Each child has their own pencil box with school tools.

Two doors will be used on the side of the building for students to enter through to decrease congestion.

Students will sanitize/wash hands frequently throughout the day. We will also do this anytime we enter the building from buses, cars and recess.

The health and safety of our students, staff and community is important. We look forward to welcoming everyone back to school tomorrow!!

As a reminder, weekly food delivery is available to families with children 18 and under, contact Adam Thomas to register.

post_text: The seventh grade students were so lucky to have Mr. John Unger, a CT graduate and one of the nine coal miners who had been trapped in the Quecreek Mine in 2002, come and talk to them today about his experience. These students have been learning about and researching survival stories as they read the book Trapped. Mr. Unger's presentation showed them what qualities someone must possess to survive in a life-threatening situation. He also gave a fantastic first-hand account of an event that is local history. We are very appreciative that Mr. Unger took the time to share his story with us and that Mr. Buncich was able to organize this visit for our classes!
